newsitem.title: USA: North Dakota corn seedings ahead of average pace.
newsitem.headline: North Dakota corn seedings ahead of average pace.

text.p: Corn seeding progress topped the five-year average pace in the week ended Sunday but cool temperatures and dry soil conditions hindered emergence, the state's agricultural statistics service said.
Corn was 51 percent seeded as of Sunday, ahead of the five-year average of 43 percent.

Soybeans were 16 percent seeded, trailing the average of 27 percent. Spring wheat was 49 percent planted, against 61 percent on average. Ten percent of the wheat had emerged, versus 34 percent on average.
Oats were 47 percent planted, versus 58 on average.
Sugarbeets were 76 percent planted, nearly identical to the five-year average of 77 percent.
Fields in the flooded Red River Valley remained wet.
"Continued standing water in parts of some eastern counties prevented any fieldwork in those areas," the report said. "Fieldwork may not begin until the end of May in flooded areas."
Topsoil moisture was rated one percent very short, 23 percent short, 66 percent adequate and 10 percent surplus.
Pasture was rated seven percent very poor, 13 poor, 32 fair, 40 good and eight excellent.
